g.text: hot air blower was used to collect data between 498 and 923 K in 50 K steps. Empty
capillary data were collected at 90, 200, 473, 573, 673, 773, and 873 K. For each data
set, the temperature was stabilised for 10 min and then data were collected for
10 min using the accumulation mode of the detector for 10-s exposure frames. Data
and Si standards at 300 K to calibrate the instru-
Instrument calibration and image integration was performed with the pyFAI
. The instrument model was recalibrated for every temperature in the
cryostat data sets in order to allow for slight detector shifts. A ﬁxed instrument
model was used for the hot air blower data. Data sets were converted to scattering
) as a function of scattering vector
is interatomic distance, using the pdfgetx3 suite
0.9 Å were applied to all data sets
) to be analysed consistently across the full
. Structural models used to ﬁt magnetite PDFs
at all temperatures were based on the supercell of the low-temperature structure
symmetry, which contains 56 unique atoms with
168 variable coordinates. A cubic model previously reﬁned against 130 K powder
was used as the reference undistorted structure. The
was used to generate a supercell of the cubic structure with

was transformed to the same cell metric (from
in order to preserve the magnitude of the distortions as generated by the ISO-
. This approximation was found to have little effect on ﬁts of
1) are shown in Supplementary Table 2. To vary the
magnitude of the structural distortion, seven structural models were constructed by
taking linear combinations of the undistorted and distorted coordinates
) for values of the Verwey shift
. Reﬁnements of structural models including simulation of termination
ripples were performed with the PDFgui software
ﬁxed structural model was used to extract the instrument-sensitive parameters
. It was not possible to mini-
directly in the reﬁnements and so the best-ﬁt value was found
ws for the seven structural models with varying ﬁxed
A ‘box-car’ reﬁnement procedure was followed where, at each temperature, each
of the seven structural models were ﬁtted to three regions of the PDF;
1.50–9.36, 9.30–16.85, and 16.80–24.60 Å, to ﬁt correlations between atoms
separated by approximate First, Second, and Third Unit Cell distances, respectively.
, and O sites, and the peak width
were reﬁned during ﬁts to data in the First Unit Cell
range. Second and Third Unit Cell ﬁts used
values from the First Unit Cell ﬁts,
was set to 0. A further constraint of equal Fe
ﬁt Third Unit Cell data sets for temperatures >150 K. Fits to 90 K First Unit Cell
for each temperature and data range was found from the
position of the minimum in the
curve ﬁtted by the arbitrary function:
c and Supplementary Fig. 2. Estimated standard deviations (esds) in the best-
values were calculated from those in
values were set to zero. The best-ﬁt First Unit Cell’s
s and their errors were calculated by linear interpolation
increments closest to the minimum value. Lattice
parameters were also ﬁtted to the diffraction data using the Rietveld method and
are shown in Supplementary Fig. 3. An approximate correlation length for the
structural distortions was calculated from the First Unit Cell
Data that support the ﬁndings of this study have been deposited at
